definition: A security mechanism that requires expending real physical energy (electricity) to validate transactions. Bitcoin miners compete to solve complex mathematical puzzles, making attacks prohibitively expensive.
A public ledger of all Bitcoin transactions, organized in blocks and linked together in a chain. Each block contains a cryptographic hash of the previous block, making it tamper-resistant.
The process of using specialized computers to solve complex mathematical problems, validating transactions and adding new blocks to the blockchain. Miners receive newly created bitcoin as a reward.

An event that occurs approximately every 4 years where the reward for mining new blocks is cut in half. This ensures Bitcoin's supply grows at a predictable, decreasing rate until reaching the 21 million cap.
The hard-coded maximum supply of Bitcoin that will ever exist. This makes Bitcoin scarce like gold, preventing inflation through unlimited creation.
The distribution of power and control across many independent participants rather than concentrating it in a single authority. Bitcoin has no CEO, no company, and no central server.
A secret number that proves ownership of bitcoin. Like a password that can't be reset, losing your private key means losing access to your bitcoin forever.
A cryptographic identifier derived from your private key, used to receive bitcoin. You can share it publicly without risking your funds, like an email address.
Software that stores your private keys and allows you to send and receive bitcoin. The bitcoin itself lives on the blockchain; your wallet just holds the keys.
The total computational power securing the Bitcoin network, measured in hashes per second. Higher hash rate = more security against attacks.
A second-layer solution built on top of Bitcoin that enables instant, low-cost transactions by keeping most activity off the main blockchain.
The smallest unit of Bitcoin, equal to 0.00000001 BTC. Named after Bitcoin's creator, Satoshi Nakamoto.
A computer running Bitcoin software that validates transactions and stores a copy of the entire blockchain. Nodes enforce the rules and keep the network decentralized.
The problem of spending the same digital money twice. Bitcoin solves this through proof-of-work and the blockchain without requiring a central authority.
The projection of physical power in, from, and through cyberspace via proof-of-work protocols. Non-lethal warfare using hash power instead of kinetic weapons to secure digital resources.
The ability to demonstrate control over resources by imposing physical costs on challengers. Applies across all domains: land, sea, air, space, and cyberspace.
The fundamental economic calculation: Benefits of attacking รท Costs of attacking. If BCR_A > 1, attack is profitable. If BCR_A < 1, attack is deterred.
A protective barrier created by Bitcoin's cumulative hash power. Like missile defense for digital resources, it requires massive physical cost (electricity) to breach.
Bitcoin's alternative to nuclear Mutually Assured Destruction. Everyone's mining secures everyone else's bitcoins, creating positive-sum security instead of zero-sum fear.
The concept of using hash rate (computational work) as a form of power projection in cyberspace, analogous to military power in physical domains.
The ability to control resources through belief manipulation rather than physical force. Examples: religious authority, legal systems, monetary control, software permissions.
The ability to control resources through demonstrable physical capability that imposes real costs on challengers. Examples: walls, weapons, proof-of-work.
A research methodology that builds explanations from systematic data analysis rather than testing pre-existing hypotheses. Used by Lowery to develop the Softwar thesis.
The fundamental economic calculation governing conflict in nature: whether attacking yields more benefit than cost. The BCR_A formula captures this.
The challenge of achieving consensus among distributed parties when some may be unreliable or malicious. Bitcoin solves this through proof-of-work.
An attack where one entity creates many fake identities to gain disproportionate influence. Bitcoin prevents this by making identity creation expensive (proof-of-work).
A theoretical attack where controlling over half the network's hash power allows rewriting transaction history. Bitcoin's massive hash rate makes this prohibitively expensive.
The method by which distributed networks agree on the state of the ledger. Bitcoin uses proof-of-work; other systems use proof-of-stake or other methods.
Inflation: currency supply increases, reducing purchasing power. Deflation: fixed supply increases value over time. Bitcoin is deflationary due to the 21M cap.
An asset that maintains purchasing power over time. Gold is a traditional store of value; Bitcoin aims to be a digital equivalent due to its scarcity.
